description: The age of the customer could influence their likelihood of churning, with younger customers being more likely to close their accounts.
Customers who use the service more frequently may be less likely to churn, as they are getting more value from the product.
Customers who have had recent interactions with customer support are more likely to churn as they may be experiencing issues with the product.
Customers who have been subscribed for a longer period of time may be less likely to churn, as they are more committed to the service.
Customers faced with a larger number of competitors in the market may be more likely to churn, as they have more options to choose from.
Customers who frequently use promotional offers may be more likely to churn, as they are more price-sensitive and less loyal to the brand.
Customers who have lower satisfaction scores are more likely to churn, as they are less happy with the product or service.
Customers with unstable financial status may be more likely to churn, as they may be looking to cut expenses.
Customers who have recently changed their usage patterns may be more likely to churn, as they may be exploring other options.
Customers who have experienced frequent network outages may be more likely to churn, as they may perceive the service as unreliable.
